{{Use Indian English|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox Convention |name = Comics Fest India |logo = Comics Fest India 2013.jpg|logosize=150px|logo_caption=Logo for the Comics Fest India, 2013 |status = Defunct |venue = [[Dilli Haat, Burari]] |location = [[New Delhi]], [[India]] |first = 2008 (Started as Nagraj Janmotsav)
2013 (Renamed to Comics Fest India) |organizer = [[Raj Comics]] |website = http://www.comicsfestindia.com/ }} '''Comics Fest India''' (previously known as Nagraj Janmotsav) was a [[Comic book convention|comic-based convention]] held in [[India]], annually at [[New Delhi]]. The event began as an annual birthday celebration for [[Nagraj]]. But the incereasing number of fans and participants made the event grow larger every year, and soon the event sprang out of the Raj Comics studios (where it started) and was held at [[Dilli Haat]], [[Pitampura]]. The event is popular for being the only convention in India that provides free gifts (including T-shirts, comic books and merchandise) to all the registered attendees. Now it is the second annual comic book convention in New Delhi, after [[Comic Con India]]. {{cite news|title=Comics Fest India Slated for 30 Nov & 1 Dec|url=http://www.animationxpress.com/index.php/latest-news/comic-fest-india-2013-slated-for-30-nov-and-1-dec|accessdate=26 November 2013|newspaper=Animation Xpress|date=19 November 2013}}{{cite web|title=A Grand Celebration of Indian Comics|url=http://www.cgtantra.com/forums/showthread.php?t=35107|work=CG Tantra|accessdate=26 November 2013}} ==History== In 2008, [[Raj Comics]] hosted 3 events namely, ''Gen-Next Writers Workshop'' (January 2008), ''Junoon Mela'' (June 2008), and ''Nagraj Janmotsav'' (4–5 October 2008). Nagraj Janmotsav was the birthday celebration of Raj Comics's flagship character Nagraj. [[File:Nagraj Janmotsav 2012.jpg|thumb|(From left-right) Manish Gupta, [[Sanjay Gupta (comics)|Sanjay Gupta]] and Manoj Gupta with the host Kshitij Sharma at Nagraj Janmotsav, 2012.]] What started as a birthday celebration for their flagship character, soon grew into an annual convention attended by several fans and creators. Raj Comics organized the initial events at Rtoonz Studios ([[Burari]]). Each year, the event kept growing both in size and space and in 2012, it was held at Dilli Haat, Pitampura.[http://in.groups.yahoo.com/group/jistmca/message/4141] ''[[Yahoo]]'', New Delhi, 5 October 2008 In 2013, Raj Comics declared that Nagraj Janmotsav will be celebrated on an even bigger scale and was called ''Comics Fest India''. This new bigger convention showcased stalls by multiple Indian publishing houses, including, but not restricted to, [[Raj Comics]], Tricolor Children Books, [[Campfire Novels]], [[Holycow Entertainment]], Paperclip Books, [[Rovolt Comics]], [[Fenil Comics]] and many other publishers.{{cite web|title=Nagraj Janmotsav and 2nd Annual Kalpana Lok Awards 2011|work=All Events|accessdate=26 November 2013}} These conventions include many contests, interactive sessions, comics launches, workshops and speeches by various novelists, editors, comic book artists and writers.{{cite book|title=Nagraj Jamotsav - 5|year=2012|publisher=Freelance Talents|location=Meerut|page=12|url=http://www.readwhere.com/publication/1672/Indian-Comics-Fandom-Vol.-1/vol/61742}}{{cite web|title=Comics Event at Dilli Haat|url=https://eventviva.com/event/257660414355526|work=Event Viva|publisher=Dilli Haat|accessdate=26 November 2013}} ==Kalpana Lok Awards== [[File:Kalpana Lok Award - 2010 (Best Author).JPG|thumb |Tarun Kumar Wahi (right) receiving the Best Script Writer Award from Raja Pocket Books CEO Mr. Manoj Gupta, 2010]] In 2010, Raj Comics celebrated its Silver Jubilee with the third Nagraj Janmotsav. During this event Raj Comics started honouring the excellence of its own creatives with an in-house award ceremony, called Kalpana Lok Awards. The celebration opened with Nagraj's Birthday followed by inaugural Kalpana lok awards. Raj Comics editors nominates creative individuals under different categories like Best - [[Penciller]], [[Webcomic]], [[Script Writer]], [[Graphic Designer]], [[Inker]], [[Colorist]]. Winners are decided by a special jury of authors and artists appointed by organizers, and the fans who can vote online on Comics Fest India as well as Raj Comics websites. Fourth edition of Kalpana Lok Awards was one of the most publicized attractions of Comics Fest India 2013.{{cite news|title=Raj Comics Silver Jubilee and Kalpana Lok Awards Ceremony|url=http://www.rajcomics.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&catid=3:newsflash&id=2374:raj-comics-silver-jubilee-and-kalpana-lok-awards-ceramony&Itemid=307|accessdate=26 November 2013|date=27 October 2010}} In 2013, during the Comics Fest India, the awards called for submissions from various publishers all over the country. The categories were expanded and several publishing houses participated in the awards. ==Comics Fest India 2013== [[File:Anupam Sinha with Dhruva Statue.jpg|thumb|Writer and artist, [[Anupam Sinha]] with the unveiled statue of his popular comic book superhero [[Super Commando Dhruva]], at Comics Fest India, 2013.]] Jointly organized by [[Punjab Kesari]] and Animation Xpress, Comics Fest India was held from 30 November – 1 December 2013 at [[Dilli Haat]], [[New Delhi]], [[India]]. In an attempt to expand the event apart from participants from previous editions many new publishers, animation companies participated, such as [[Amar Chitra Katha]], [[Diamond Comics]], Holy Cow Entertainment, Any Magic Studios, [[Pustak Mahal]], Geek Mentors Studios, Fenil Comics, Campfire Graphic Novels, [[Lotpot]], [[Freelance talents]], [[National Book Trust]]. The event contained various workshops, launches and activities. These mini events included; fan introduction, workshops on creative writing, storytelling and publishing; contests such as cosplay, comic trivia and one liners. Also, many fans performed various comic skits on stage and to entertain little kids, magic show and a drawing competition were held. Raj Comics also unveiled the life size statues of its superheroes during the event. [[Mukesh Khanna]] attended the event as a special guest.{{cite web|title=कॉमिक्स फेस्ट इंडिया 2013|url=http://mohitness.com/comics-fest-india-2013/|work=Mohitness|accessdate=26 November 2013}} After having been the host for previous two Nagraj Janmotsav Events, Delhi based emcee Kshitij Sharma once again hosted the on-stage proceedings for Comics Fest India, 2013 == See also == * [[Comic Con India]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131203082502/http://www.comicsfestindia.com/ Comics Fest India Official Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131203010544/http://www.paperclipbooks.in/ Paperclip Books, website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131203073739/http://comicaddicts.com/raj-exclusive-preview-aadam-2/ Raj Exclusive Preview] at ''[[Comics Addcits]]'' *[https://www.facebook.com/comicsfestivalindia Comics Fest India Official Facebook Page] *[https://www.facebook.com/rajcomics Raj Comics Facebook Page] *[http://www.punjabkesari.in/ Punjab Kesari Hindi Newspaper Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20010303083546/http://www.diamondcomic.com/ Diamond Comics] *[http://www.campfire.co.in/ Campfire Graphic Novels] *[http://www.amarchitrakatha.com/ Amar Chitra Katha] *[http://www.pustakmahal.com/ Pustak Mahal] *[http://www.nbtindia.gov.in/ National Book Trust] *[http://www.fenilcomics.com/ Fenil Comics] *[http://www.holycow.in/ Holy Cow Entertainment] [[Category:Defunct comics conventions]] [[Category:Indian comics]] [[Category:Comics awards]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2008]] [[Category:Culture of Delhi]] [[Category:Fan conventions]] [[Category:Raj Comics]] [[Category:Comics-related organizations]] [[Category:2008 establishments in India]] [[Category:Companies based in New Delhi]]

revision.comment: /* Development */Fixing [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links|links to disambiguation pages]], replaced: [[open source]] → [[open-source software|open-source]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Cortex Command | image = Cortex command.jpg | caption = Title screen of Cortex Command | developer = Data Realms LLC | publisher = Data Realms LLC | modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|Multiplayer]] | released = 28 September 2012<ref>http://devlog.datarealms.com/cortex-command/cortex-command-1-0-playtest-preview/</ref> | genre = [[Action game|Action]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Mac OS X]], [[Linux]] | director = Daniel Tabár }}
'''''Cortex Command''''' is a [[2D computer graphics|two-dimensional]] [[side-scrolling video game|side-scrolling]] [[action game]] developed by Swedish studio Data Realms since 2001.
== Gameplay == [[File:Cortex Command video game screenshot.png|thumb|left|''Cortex Command'' screenshot.]] The player takes the role of a stationary or mobile "brain", which can take control of other purchased units in order to accomplish objectives. Missions range from tasks such as retrieving a control chip in a cave filled with zombies to defending the brain from attack. As the brain is weak, the player must manage his resources carefully, protecting the brain, mining gold and fighting off enemies.
The game includes the ability for players to create [[mod (computer gaming)|mods]] (additions and changes to the game) with the built in [[Lua (programming language)|Lua]] programming applet and simple scripting.
== Development == The [[game engine]] was designed and built by Dan Tabár, using several [[open-source software|open-source]] [[library (computing)|libraries]]. The [[Graphical user interface|GUI]] was built by Jason Boettcher, the artwork is by Arne Niklas Jansson, and the [[macOS]] port is by Chris Kruger,<ref name="cc_home" /><ref name="play">{{Cite news| last = Griffin | first = Mike | title = Cortex Command: Brain slayers in outer space | newspaper = [[Play (US magazine)|Play]] | pages = 64–65 | date = June 2008 | url =| postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref> while the Linux port was developed by Jesus Higueras.
The game was first released as an [[open beta]] and was later released for purchase with a time-limited [[game demo|demo]] version available as well.
As of May 2008, the game was described as being in development for approximately seven years, with Dan Tabár quitting his job in mid-2006 to work full-time on the project.<ref name="indiegames" /> No versions for game consoles are planned.<ref name="indiegames" /> The game allows several components to be modified using [[Lua (programming language)|Lua]] and [[INI file|INI]] files, such as Scenes (or levels), Actors, Weapons, and more.<ref name="indiegames">{{cite web |url = http://www.indiegames.com/blog/2008/05/interview_dan_tabar_cortex_com.html | title = Interview: Dan Tabár (Cortex Command)| author = W., Tim| publisher =indiegames.com | date = 2008-05-27| accessdate= 2008-07-01}}</ref> Influences for the game include the ''[[X-COM: UFO Defense]]'' series.<ref name="play" /> {{asof|2009}}, the full version is still being refined (as the game is still in extensive development), but includes unlimited play and extra features unavailable in the demo.<ref name="cc_home">{{cite web |title=Cortex Command |url=http://www.datarealms.com/games.php |author= |publisher=Data Realms LLC |date= |accessdate=2008-07-27}}</ref>
== Plot == Despite the fact that the main story has been scrapped as of now, Cortex Command does have some background lore. Sometime in the mid-to-far future after humanity suffered a war brought on by a certain religious group, "a curious symbiosis" between man and machine was formed. This eventually led to humans becoming advanced enough to ditch their bodies and take their brains anywhere. This in turn, led to space travel finally becoming feasible since aging is either non-existent or slowed down to a very slow state. This leads to humans making contact with alien life forms, in a desperate attempt for humans to fit in, they establish TradeStar. TradeStar is one of the biggest if not the biggest corporations in the whole Milky Way galaxy. But humanity doesn't stop there, despite humanity having long abandoned their bodies, they still kept the stubborn will to fight. With contracting being open to the highest bidder, prospectors fight on earth-like planets with rich gold deposits, while being supplied by companies like Alchiral or TradeStar.
== Reception == The control system for the unfinished version of the game has been described as "too fiddly to be considered entertaining" in 2007.<ref name="pcformat">{{cite web |author=Alan Dexter |title=Cortex Command |publisher=[[PC Format]] |url=http://blog.pcformat.co.uk/page/pcformat?entry=cortex_command |date=2007-03-05 |accessdate=2008-07-26 }}</ref> Others described the game as requiring patience, asking players to "take [their] time and experiment".<ref name="rps">{{cite web |author=Jim Rossignol |title=Cortex Command |publisher=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]] |url=http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2008/04/23/cortex-command/ |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2008-07-26 }}</ref> The game has been compared to other games in the genre, such as ''[[GunBound]]''<ref name="pcformat" /> and ''[[Worms (series)|Worms]]''.<ref name="rps" /> Positive reviews praise the detailed physics, as well as the chaotic gameplay.
''Cortex Command'' was the ''Indie Games'' Game of the Month for April 2008.<ref name="indiegames_gotm">{{cite web |author= |title=Game of the Month, April 2008 |publisher=indiegames.com |url=http://www.indiegames.com/gameofthemonth/ |date= |accessdate=2008-07-26 }}</ref>
''Cortex Command'' won the Audience Award and Technical Excellence award at the 2009 [[Independent Games Festival]].<ref name="gamasutr">{{cite web|author= |title=11th Independent Games Festival |publisher=[[gamasutra.com]] | url=http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=22919 |date=2009-03-26 |accessdate=2009-03-30}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.datarealms.com/games.php|''Cortex Command'' official website}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name= Dawn Brancheau |image= Dawn Brancheau - Riders on the Storm (cropped, full body).jpg |image_caption= Dawn Brancheau at the ''Believe'' show, at SeaWorld, Orlando, Florida, in 2006 |birth_name= Dawn Therese LoVerde<ref name=Obituary/> |birth_date= April 16, 1969 |birth_place= [[Cedar Lake, Indiana]], U.S. |death_date= February 24, 2010 (aged 40) |death_place= [[Orlando, Florida]], U.S. |death_cause= [[Drowning]] and [[blunt-force trauma]] |resting_place = [[Holy Sepulchre Cemetery (Worth, Illinois)|Holy Sepulchre Cemetery]], [[Worth Township, Cook County, Illinois|Worth Township, Illinois]], U.S.<ref>[https://www.orlandosentinel.com/business/tourism/os-brancheau-funeral-20100301-story.html ''Orlando Sentinel'']</ref> |occupation= SeaWorld trainer |spouse= {{Marriage|Scott Brancheau|1996|2010}} |years_active= 1994–2010 }}
'''Dawn Therese Brancheau''' ([[née]] '''LoVerde''', April 16, 1969 – February 24, 2010) was an American senior animal trainer at [[SeaWorld]].<ref name=Cridlin/><ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/> She worked with [[orca]]s at [[SeaWorld Orlando]] for fifteen years, including a leading role in revamping the ''[[Shamu (SeaWorld show)|Shamu]]'' show,<ref name=Cridlin/><ref name=Kassab20060109/> and was SeaWorld's [[Poster child|poster girl]].<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/><ref name=Hargrove/><ref name=Believe20130514/> She was killed by an orca, [[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]],<ref name=OSHRC/> becoming the only SeaWorld trainer to be killed by an animal. However, her death was the third fatality associated with Tilikum, and many other trainers have been seriously injured by orcas.<ref name=OSHRC/><ref name=Stetz20100421/><ref name=Hoyt1992/>
== Life and career == Brancheau was born Dawn Therese LoVerde in [[Cedar Lake, Indiana]] and was the youngest of six children.<ref name=Obituary/><ref name=Jacobson/> She had a passionate love of animals<ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> and set her heart on becoming a ''[[Shamu]]'' trainer during a family vacation to [[Orlando]].<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/><ref name=Kassab20060109/><ref name=Jacobson/><ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> She graduated from the [[University of South Carolina]] with degrees in [[psychology]] and [[animal behavior]].<ref name=Jacobson/><ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> Away from work, she volunteered at a local animal shelter,<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/> looked after two chocolate [[Labrador]]s,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dawnsfoundation.org/dawn-s-story.html|title=The Dawn Brancheau Foundation|publisher=}}</ref> and kept a variety of stray ducks, chickens, rabbits, and small birds at her home.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/>
[[File:Katina & Dawn.jpg|thumb|Brancheau on a slide out, which is a platform covered by less than a foot of water, with killer whale ''Katina'' in SeaWorld Orlando]] Brancheau spent two years working with [[dolphin]]s at [[Six Flags Great Adventure]] in [[New Jersey]] before beginning her career at [[SeaWorld Orlando]] in 1994, initially working with [[otter]]s and [[sea lion]]s.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/>{{rp|347}}<ref name=Kassab20060109/><ref name=Jacobson/> In 1996, the same year she married Scott Brancheau,<ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> a SeaWorld stunt [[water skier]],<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/> she started working with orcas.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/>{{rp|347}}<ref name=Kassab20060109/><ref name=Jacobson/>
In 2000, she appeared on [[NBC]] affiliate [[WESH]] and talked about staying physically fit in order to deal with the intense rigor of working with killer whales.<ref name=WESH13533140/> She ran marathons, cycled, and lifted weights to stay in good shape. In 2006, her decade of work with orcas was profiled, including her leadership role in a two- to three-year revamp of the ''[[Shamu (SeaWorld show)|Shamu]]'' show.<ref name=Cridlin/><ref name=Kassab20060109/> Brancheau acknowledged the dangers of working in close proximity to orcas.<ref name=Kassab20060109/> As a senior trainer, she appeared in various SeaWorld public performances for many years.<ref name=Cridlin/><ref name=WESH13533140/> The Shamu show's interaction of animal trainers with orcas was regarded as SeaWorld's star attraction.<ref name=ABC/>
She was featured on SeaWorld [[billboard]]s throughout Orlando.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/> Judge [[Brett Kavanaugh]], a dissenting judge in a legal case involving her death ([[#Safety|see below]]), stated that "To be fearless, courageous, tough – to perform a sport or activity at the highest levels of human capacity, even in the face of known physical risk – is among the greatest forms of personal achievement for many who take part in these activities."<ref name=USCA121375/>{{rp|24}}
== Death == On February 24, 2010, Brancheau performed a ''Dine with Shamu'' show with [[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]],<ref name=Hoare/> the largest orca at [[SeaWorld Orlando]]. In this setting, guests ate at an open-air restaurant while watching the performance poolside as the orca was exercised and fed.<ref name=OSHRC/><ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> As part of the end-of-show routine, she was at the edge of the pool, rubbing Tilikum's head. She was lying with her face next to Tilikum's on a slide-out, which is a platform submerged about a foot into the water. Sources stated that she was pulled into the water by her ponytail;<ref name=CNN20100224/><ref name=Pilkington20100225/><ref name=Myers/> the orca's move seems to have been very quick, pulling her underwater and drowning her.<ref name=Pilkington20100225/><ref name=Taylor20100429/><ref name=LAT20100224/> At least a dozen patrons witnessed Brancheau in the water with Tilikum. Employees used nets and threw food at Tilikum in an attempt to distract him.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/> Moving from pool to pool in the complex, they eventually directed Tilikum to a smaller, medical pool, where it would be easier to calm him. The orca subsequently released Brancheau's body.
The autopsy report said that Brancheau died from drowning and blunt force trauma. Her spinal cord was severed, and she had sustained fractures to her [[mandible|jawbone]], ribs, and a [[cervical vertebra]]. Her scalp was completely torn off from her head, her left arm had been ripped off near the shoulder, and her left elbow and left knee had been dislocated.<ref name=Autopsy-DB/>
Brancheau was buried at [[Holy Sepulchre Cemetery (Worth, Illinois)|Holy Sepulchre Cemetery]] in [[Worth Township, Cook County, Illinois]].<ref>[https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/Funeral-Services-Set-for-SeaWorld-Trainer-85815077.html NBC Chicago]</ref>
== Consequences == ===Safety=== No SeaWorld trainer entered a pool to perform a show with an orca following Brancheau's death.<ref name=Hargrove/>{{rp|7}}<ref name=Schneider20110919/> Immediately afterwards, SeaWorld disallowed trainers from being in the water with any orca.<ref name=Hargrove/><ref name=Lee20100224/> This internal, voluntary prohibition was similar to what had happened after some other injuries to animal trainers. Each time, the temporary pause was then lifted by SeaWorld. However, on this occasion, the ban was solidified by an [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) intervention. This led SeaWorld to repeatedly seek the lifting of various aspects of OSHA's citations and rulings until 2014, when it accepted that further attempts to overturn OSHA were not feasible.<ref name=USCA121375/><ref name=Kuo20140411/><ref name=Lee20140820/>
Although Brancheau is the only SeaWorld trainer killed by an animal, her death was the third fatality associated with [[Tilikum (orca)|Tilikum]]<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/><ref name=OSHRC/> and the fourth by a captive orca.<ref name=OSHRC/> Since orcas were first placed in captivity in the 1960s, there have been more than 40 documented [[Killer whale attacks on humans|safety incidents]], with "dozens" of trainers being seriously injured by various orcas.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/><ref name=Hargrove/><ref name=Stetz20100421/><ref name=Lee20100224/><ref name=Zimmerman-BitW/> After a 2006 attack,<ref name=Stetz20100421/><ref>{{cite web | last=DeCourcey | first=Danielle | title=Sea World Just Took a Blow That Will Change the Controversial Company Forever | website=ATTN: | date=2016-03-17 | url=http://www.attn.com/stories/6647/sea-world-animal-welfare-changes | accessdate=2016-09-10|quote=a trainer named Ken Peters was bitten and pulled under water by a different whale named Kasatka in 2006, four years before Brancheau was killed. The whale pulled him around for 8 minutes until he finally swam to the edge of the pool visibly shaken}}</ref> an OSHA investigation in 2007 concluded that, "The continuing factors to the incident, in the simplest of terms, is that swimming with captive orcas is inherently dangerous, and if someone hasn't been killed already, it is only a matter of time before it does happen." SeaWorld successfully challenged the report, which OSHA agreed to withdraw.<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP/>
Additionally, two months before Brancheau's death, another SeaWorld-owned orca, Keto, killed a trainer, [[Death of Alexis Martínez|Alexis Martínez]], at [[Loro Parque]]'s ''Orca Ocean'' in the [[Canary Islands]].<ref name=Zimmerman-BitW>{{cite web | last=Zimmermann | first=Tim | title=Blood in the Water | website=Outside Online | date=2011-07-15 | url=http://www.outsideonline.com/1886916/blood-water | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> Four SeaWorld orcas had been delivered by wide-body cargo plane in February 2006, and SeaWorld staff trained a group of Loro Parque trainers in [[San Antonio]] and Orlando.<ref name=Zimmerman-BitW/> In September 2006, Brancheau had pulled a temporary rotation at Loro Parque and reportedly enjoyed working with Martínez.<ref name=Zimmerman-BitW/> SeaWorld discontinued water work at its three parks for about a week immediately after Martínez's death.<ref name=Zimmerman-BitW/>
On August 23, 2010, SeaWorld was fined US$75,000 by OSHA for three safety violations, one directly related to Brancheau's death.<ref name=Kirby-TP>{{cite web|title=Exclusive: SeaWorld Appeals Ruling in Trainer's Death as Eyewitness Interviews Are Released|url=http://www.takepart.com/article/2012/11/20/seaworld-appeals-ruling-trainers-death-eyewitness-interviews-are-released|date=20 November 2012|first=David|last=Kirby|publisher=TakePart|access-date=2016-02-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160212024605/http://www.takepart.com/article/2012/11/20/seaworld-appeals-ruling-trainers-death-eyewitness-interviews-are-released#|archive-date=2016-02-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2010|first=Harris M.|last=Lentz III|page=44|publisher=McFarland & Company|year=2011}}</ref> OSHA maintained that SeaWorld "willfully" endangered its employees and stated that the company "(shows) Plain indifference to, or intentional disregard for, employee safety and health." SeaWorld issued a statement that called OSHA's findings "unfounded".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/unleashed/2010/08/tilikum-orca-sea-world-orlando-osha.html|title=OSHA fines SeaWorld for worker safety issues following orca trainer's death|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=August 23, 2010|accessdate=August 4, 2012}}</ref> SeaWorld challenged the OSHA fine and the safety report in legal proceedings, stating that "OSHA's allegations in this citation are unsupported by any evidence or precedent and reflect a fundamental lack of understanding of the safety requirements associated with marine mammal care."<ref>{{cite web|last=Garcia|first=Jason|title=SeaWorld-OSHA hearing in recess until mid-November|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2011-09-23/business/os-seaworld-osha-killer-whale-20110923_1_tilikum-brancheau-killer-whales|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 23, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SeaWorld Will Fight $75k Fine in Trainer Dawn Brancheau's Death|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-20014463-504083.html|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> At a preliminary hearing in 2011, one of these citations was withdrawn by OSHA.<ref name=OSHRC/>
Subsequently, in late May 2012, Judge Ken S. Welsch formally sided with OSHA over SeaWorld's orca safety practices.<ref name=OSHRC>{{Cite web |url=http://www.oshrc.gov/decisions/pdf_2012/10-1705.pdf# |title=Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission OSHRC, Docket No. 10-1705, Secretary of Labor v. SeaWorld of Florida, LLC. |access-date=2016-04-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915121648/http://www.oshrc.gov/decisions/pdf_2012/10-1705.pdf# |archive-date=2012-09-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Welsch was sharply critical of SeaWorld's assertion that it was unaware that working with killer whales posed a hazard to employees. Welsch stated it is "implausible" and "difficult to reconcile" with comments repeatedly made by management and with the litany of trainer incidents and injuries that have occurred over the years. Welsch did, however, agree that the fine classification was too severe and had it downgraded – from "willful" (total of $75,000 for the 2 citations) to "serious" (total of $12,000) – stating that the company had emphasized trainer safety, even if the safety procedures weren't effective.<ref name=OSHRC/><ref name=Kirby-TP/>
The court was scathing in its assessment of SeaWorld's expert, Mr. Andrews', opinion, "that Tilikum grabbed Ms. Brancheau by the hair out of curiosity because he was unfamiliar with it" as "speculative" and having "no basis in fact". Accordingly, "The court accords it no weight." The court criticized SeaWorld's "closed system" of logic, which blamed trainers for their injuries, by a flawed circularity of reasoning whereby, "SeaWorld believes it 'condition[s] all aspects of behavior.' All behavior is thus predictable. If an undesirable behavior occurs, it is because the trainer missed a known precursor. Ergo, the trainer is always at fault for the killer whale's undesirable behavior. In this closed system, any injuries sustained by a trainer will always be traceable to human error. It is not the operant conditioning program that is inadequate; it is the performance of the trainer that is flawed."
The court made clear that while SeaWorld's expert, "Mr Andrews concludes his report by stating, 'My expert opinion is that SeaWorld can safely allow trainers to closely interact with killer whales, including waterwork, with the administrative and engineering controls that existed prior to February 24, 2010' (Exh. C-15, p. 10)," the court found otherwise: "As noted in the section addressing the recognized hazard, SeaWorld's own incident reports demonstrate that its safety program, either due to misplaced faith in operant conditioning or due to human error in implementing operant conditioning, exposes its trainers to the risks of death or serious physical injury." The court amplified this, aligning itself with the OSHA expert witness: "Dr. Duffus stated, '[T]he training program that SeaWorld uses is influential. It does work. My point is that it does not work all the time' (Tr. 911). The court agrees with Dr. Duffus. SeaWorld's training program is highly detailed, well-communicated, and intensive. Yet it cannot remove the element of unpredictability inherent in working with killer whales."<ref name=OSHRC/>
Welsch made it clear that his ruling only applies "to the work trainers do during shows and not at other times, such as during medical procedures or 'relationship-building' sessions... As a custodian SeaWorld has an ethical duty to provide for the whales' needs... husbandry activities require a certain amount of contact between the trainers and whales... unlike performances, which can successfully continue without the trainers in the water." OSHA did state that it would accept other means of protection as long as it provided equal or greater safety as the physical barriers. SeaWorld looked at rising pool floors and "spare air" systems in an attempt to get their staff back in the water during shows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2012-05-30/business/os-seaworld-osha-ruling-20120530_1_seaworld-killer-whale-trainers-killer-whales-marine-park-operator|title=SeaWorld OSHA ruling: Judge rules SeaWorld killer-whale trainers must be protected by physical barriers|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|date=May 30, 2012|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Given the court rulings, even after 2010, although water work during shows stopped, SeaWorld trainers still entered the water with orcas during "safety desensitization training" and for other care.<ref name=Lee20140820/>
SeaWorld filed a series of appeals, seeking to return to water performances.<ref name=ABC/><ref name=Karlamangla/> In 2012, a special Labor Department commission declined to hear the case.<ref name=Kirby-TP/> Since the ''[[Shamu (SeaWorld show)|Shamu]]'' show's interaction of animal trainers with orcas was seen as having been SeaWorld's star attraction,<ref name=ABC/> SeaWorld contended that it was fundamental to its business.<ref name=ABC/><ref name=USCA121375/> In April 2014, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit|US Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia]] denied a "petition for review".<ref name=USCA121375/><ref name=Kuo20140411/><ref name=Lee20140820/> In 2015, SeaWorld was cited again, in [[San Diego]], for not adequately protecting orca trainers.<ref name=AP20160317/>
Although Brancheau's widower, Scott Brancheau, hired a [[Chicago]] law firm that specializes in [[wrongful-death]] litigation, he has not taken any legal action against SeaWorld.<ref name=Garcia-SWTF/>
===''Blackfish''=== {{Main|Blackfish (film)}} Brancheau's death is a focus of the documentary ''[[Blackfish (film)|Blackfish]]'',<ref name=cnn20160319>{{cite web|url=http://wtvr.com/2016/03/18/after-seaworld-a-blackfish-effect-on-circuses-and-zoos/ |title=After SeaWorld, a 'Blackfish effect' on circuses and zoos?|website=WTVR|via=CNN Wire|date=March 19, 2016}}</ref><ref name=bloomberg20160317>{{cite web | last=Kay | first=Jennifer | last2=Schneider | first2=Mike | title=SeaWorld to Stop Breeding Orcas, Making Them Perform Tricks | website=Bloomberg.com | date=2016-03-17 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-17/urgent-seaworld-says-it-will-end-killer-whale-breeding-program | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> which criticizes keeping orcas in captivity,<ref name=IWI/> and her death awakened a national conversation about the issue.<ref name=Kirby-DaSW>{{cite book|title=Death at SeaWorld: Shamu and the Dark Side of Killer Whales in Captivity|first=David|last=Kirby|authorlink=David Kirby (journalist)|publisher=Macmillan|date=July 17, 2012|quote=What's more, the killing of Ms. Brancheau woke up a previously inattentive media to a gripping story and a bruising nation debate — one that would soon drag in the courts, Congress, and even the Obama administration into a roiling conflict}}</ref> The director, Gabriela Cowperthwaite, argued that the claim that the orca had targeted Brancheau because she had worn her hair in a long [[ponytail]] was [[conjecture]] and that "there had to be more to this story".<ref name=IWI/>
Her family has said they are grateful that the film has brought attention to the issue of animal welfare. However, they also added that "''Blackfish'' is not Dawn's story" and that "Since Dawn's death in 2010, the media has focused mainly on the whales. A human life was lost that day, and it feels as though some believe her death was just a footnote."<ref name=Garcia20140121/>
===SeaWorld=== Brancheau's death has been seen as a factor in starting a trajectory of recalibration for SeaWorld.<ref name=Kirby-DaSW/><ref name=fox>{{cite web|title=SeaWorld phasing out killer whale breeding|website=OrlandoSentinel.com|date=2016-03-17|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/os-seaworld-phasing-out-killer-whale-breeding-orlando-news-now-20160317-premiumvideo.html|accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref name=Simmons>{{cite web|title=SeaWorld shocker bad for species preservation|website=OrlandoSentinel.com|date=2016-03-19|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/opinion/os-ed-seaworld-whale-breed-end-bad-for-conservation-032016-20160319-story.html|accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last=Bearzi | first=Maddalena | title=The Dark Era of Orca Shows is Ending | website=National Geographic Society (blogs) | date=2016-03-18 | url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2016/03/18/the-dark-era-of-orca-shows-is-ending/ | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> In addition to the impact of OSHA-imposed safety-based abatements of previous work practices to prevent further similar events, Cowperthwaite began working on ''Blackfish'' in 2010 following Brancheau's death,<ref name=Kaufman>{{Cite news|first=Amy |last=Kaufman|newspaper=Los Angeles Times | title='Blackfish' filmmaker 'never imagined' her documentary on SeaWorld would have such a major effect | date=2016-03-18 | url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-blackfish-director-on-seaworld-orca-breeding-20160318-story.html | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title='Blackfish' Director On Orcas In Captivity | website=The Huffington Post | date=2013-01-23 | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/23/gabriela-cowperthwaite-blackfish_n_2528286.html | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref> initially having questions about SeaWorld's "ponytail hypothesis".<ref name=IWI/> Cowperthwaite's background research suggested to her that there were problems with keeping captive orcas; SeaWorld disagreed, characterizing the film as propaganda.<ref name=Kirby-DaSW/><ref name=WESH24031120>{{cite web|url=http://www.wesh.com/themeparks/other/seaworld-blackfish-is-propaganda-not-documentary/24031120|title=SeaWorld: 'Blackfish' is propaganda, not documentary|first=Andrea|last=Dennis|publisher=}}</ref>
After its release in 2013, the film awakened a national dialogue about the issue.<ref name=Kirby-DaSW/> SeaWorld struggled with the effect of ''Blackfish'' on public perception,<ref name=cnn20160319/><ref name=fox/> and there were some cancellations by music performers who had planned to hold shows at SeaWorld.<ref name=bloomberg20160317/><ref name=WESH24031120/><ref name="Gibson">{{cite news|title=The Documentary Blackfish Is Still Creating Waves at SeaWorld|first=Megan|last=Gibson|date=December 11, 2013|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> SeaWorld transitioned to being a publicly traded company in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | last=Alden | first=William | title=Public Offering Values SeaWorld at $2.5 Billion | website=DealBook | date=2013-04-20 | url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2013/04/18/seaworld-prices-i-p-o-at-top-of-range/ | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref>
Lawmakers in California and the US House of Representatives proposed legislation to phase out orca captivity, and the California Coastal Commission moved in 2015 to ban orca breeding.<ref name=Manby>{{cite web | last=Manby | first=Joel | title=SeaWorld CEO: We're ending our orca breeding program. Here's why. | website=latimes.com | date=2016-03-17 | url=http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-0317-manby-sea-world-orca-breeding-20160317-story.html | accessdate=2016-09-10}}</ref><ref name=bloomberg20160317/> SeaWorld announced it was discontinuing its program of artificial insemination breeding of captive orcas<ref name=cnn20160319/><ref name=bloomberg20160317/><ref name=fox/><ref name=Simmons/><ref name=Kaufman/> and was partnering with the [[Humane Society of the United States]] to work against commercial whaling and seal hunts, shark finning, and ocean pollution and increase its focus on rescue operations.<ref name=Manby/>
===Statutory confidentiality=== In 2011, Florida passed Statute 406.136, which provides for confidentiality of media obtained by public agencies that depicts or records the killing of a person.<ref name=Calvert>Calvert C. ''Cultural Voyeurism''. in: ''Encyclopedia of Media Violence''. Editor Matthew S. Eastin. SAGE Publications, 2013 pages 96–99 {{ISBN|9781483340111}}</ref>{{rp|98}} The law was partly a response to the circumstances of Brancheau's death.<ref name=Calvert/> Local government investigators and OSHA had obtained SeaWorld's video surveillance footage, which captured her death, as well as photographs, which showed the effects of the attack. News organizations tried to obtain these media items as records in public custody, but her family expressed privacy considerations and sought to limit "voyeuristic gawking".<ref name=Calvert/>
On behalf of the family, [[Jon L. Mills|Mills]] argued in court that disclosure of media by state agencies is equivalent to dissemination, based on the [[Nikki Catsouras photographs controversy|Catsouras]] case, in which retrospective attempts to limit public access have not been fully successful.<ref>Mills JL. ''Privacy and Press Intrusions: New Media, Old Law''. in: ''The Right to Privacy in the Light of Media Convergence: Perspectives from Three Continents''. Volume 3 of Media Convergence / Medienkonvergenz. Editors: Dieter Dörr, Russell L. Weaver. Publisher: Walter de Gruyter, 2012. {{ISBN|9783110276152}}</ref> The confidentiality considerations turn on issues that resemble those in the case of the [[murder of Meredith Emerson]] in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]; the laws that Georgia and Florida enacted in response to these situations are similar.<ref name=Calvert/>
===Foundation=== The Dawn Brancheau Foundation was created by her family in Brancheau's honor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox35orlando.com/home/96501881-story|title=The Dawn Brancheau Foundation: 6 years after her death|first=|last=FOX|publisher=}}</ref>

<ref name=USCA121375>[https://consumermediallc.files.wordpress.com/2014/04/12-1375-1487925.pdf United States Court of Appeals Argued November 12, 2013 Decided April 11, 2014 No. 12-1375 SeaWorld of Florida, LLC, Petitioner v. Thomas E. Perez, Secretary, United States Department of Labor]</ref>
<ref name=WESH13533140>{{cite web|url=http://www.wesh.com/wesh-2-interviewed-late-seaworld-trainer-in-2000/13533140|title=WESH 2 interviewed late SeaWorld trainer in 2000|publisher=WESH|date=February 24, 2010}}</ref>
<ref name=Zimmerman-TKitP>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yuMW5r7C29EC&pg=PA331&dq=Dawn+Brancheau&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi50ZG9rOzLAhWjtoMKHdqHDYkQ6AEIMzAE#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Best American Science and Nature Writing 2011: The Best American Series|editors=Mary Roach, Tim Folger|first=Tim|last=Zimmerman|pages=329f|chapter=The Killer in the Pool|quote=Few people were better at it than top SeaWorld trainer Dawn Brancheau, who, at forty, was blond, vivacious, and literally the poster girl for the marine park in Orlando, Florida, appearing on billboards around the city.|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|date=October 4, 2011}}</ref>
}}

11033 V 5000 {{small|(SD)}} | cable serv 1 = [[Numericable]] (France) | cable chan 1 = Channel 404 {{small|(SD)}} | iptv serv 2 = [[Bouygues Telecom|Bbox TV]] (France) | iptv chan 2 = Channel 601 {{small|(SD)}} | iptv serv 1 = [[Free (ISP)|Freebox TV]] (France) | iptv chan 1 = Channel 556 {{small|(HD)}} | online serv 1 = [[Echourouk Group|Echourouk Channels]] (Algeria) | online chan 1 = [https://tv.echoroukonline.com/live/ Watch live] {{small|(HD)}} | online serv 2 = [[myTV (Arabic)|myTV]] (U.S.) | online chan 2 = [http://my-tv.us Watch live] {{small|(HD)}} }} '''Echorouk TV''' ({{lang-ar|الشروق تي في}}) is an Arabic language [[satellite]] [[television channel]] broadcasting from [[Algiers]]. Echourouk TV was set up by [[Echourouk Group]] with a number of Arab [[intellectuals]] from [[Algeria]] and the [[Arab World]]. == History == Echorouk TV was founded on 1 November 2011, it has started to broadcast its programs on 6 March 2012. == Operation == ; Chief executive officer: * Ali Fodil ; Commercial/marketing director: * ; News director: * == Other services == === Echorouk TV HD === Echorouk TV HD, a [[simulcast]] of Echourouk TV in [[High-definition television|high-definition]] (HD), was launched in {{Start date|2015|6|18}}. The channel simulcasts a network version of Echourouk TV in High Definition, with HD versions of its programs. === Video-on-demand === [[File:Echourouk Channels logo.png|thumb|Logo of ''Echorouk Channels'', the channel's website.]] Echorouk TV provides [[video on demand]] access for delayed viewing of the channel's programming via its desktop and mobile website at EchouroukOnline.com, which allows users to view past and present episodes of Echourouk TV shows in addition to its live programming stream. == Programming == {{Main article|List of programs broadcast by Echorouk TV}} == Brand identity == File:الشروق تي في مارس 2012- يونيو 2012.jpg|{{Start date|2012|3}} – {{End date|2012|6}} {{Start date|2012|6}} – {{End date|2013|4}} File:Echourouk TV former logo.svg|{{Start date|2013|4}} – {{End date|2014|10}} File:Echourouk TV logo.svg|{{Start date|2014|10}} – Current File:Echourouk TV HD logo.jpg|{{Start date|2015|6}} – {{End date|2015|7}} (HD version) == See also == * ''[[DZ Comedy Show]]'' == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|https://tv.echoroukonline.com/echorouk-tv/}} {{ar icon}} {{Television in Algeria}} [[Category:Arab media]] [[Category:Television in Algeria]] [[Category:Arabic-language television stations]] [[Category:Arabic-language television]] [[Category:Echourouk Group| ]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2011]] [[Category:Television stations in Algeria]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Egypt's Ten Greatest Discoveries | image = | caption = | camera = | picture_format = | audio_format = | runtime = 120 minutes (including commercials) | creator = [[Zahi Hawass]] | developer = | executive_producer = | starring = [[Zahi Hawass]] | narrated = | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = {{CAN}}
{{EGY}} | language = English | network = [[Discovery Channel]] | first_aired = April 6, 2008 | last_aired = | num_episodes = 1 | list_episodes = | website = }} '''Egypt's Ten Greatest Discoveries''' is a documentary on the [[Discovery Channel]], written and directed by Ben Mole and hosted by [[Zahi Hawass]], featuring a list of the top ten discoveries of [[Ancient Egyptian]] sites and artifacts which are of cultural significance to the country. The list was compiled by Hawass with the assistance of some of the world's leading [[egyptology|Egyptologists]]. Each discovery has a theme centered on a part of everyday life in Ancient Egypt. For six of those discoveries, a certain emphasis is placed on how some of their themes have managed to influence modern life. The documentary concludes with a short segment on how the practice of [[mummy|mummification]] influenced modern [[surgery]], with both procedures sharing much of the same techniques. ==The List== The list of discoveries presented on the show. The discoveries are listed in the order they were presented. {| class="wikitable" |- ! # ! Discovery ! Location ! Theme ! Influence on Modern Life |- | 1 | [[Khufu ship]] | [[Giza pyramid complex]] | [[Ancient Egyptian technology#Navigation and Trade|Navigation and Trade by the Ancient Egyptians]] | Fast [[shipping]] |- | 2 | [[Unfinished obelisk]] | [[Aswan]] | [[Ancient Egyptian technology#Structures and construction|Ancient Egyptian construction techniques]] | Fast [[construction]] |- | 3 | [[Great Pyramid of Giza|The Great Pyramid]] | [[Giza pyramid complex]] | [[Social hierarchy]] | [[Labour unions]] |- | 4 | [[KV62|Tomb of Tutankhamun]] | [[Valley of the Kings]] | Ancient Egyptian treasures | None |- | 5 | [[Deir el-Medina|The Town of the Tomb Builders]] | Near [[Luxor]] | Everyday Life | None |- | 6 | [[KV17|Tomb of Seti I]] | [[Valley of the Kings]] | [[Afterlife#Afterlife in Ancient Egyptian religion|Ancient Egyptian views on the afterlife]] | None |- | 7 | Lost Temple of [[Akhmim]] | Akhmim | Mysteries of Ancient Egypt | None |- | 8 | [[Abu Simbel#The Greater Temple|The Greater Temple of Abu Simbel]] | [[Abu Simbel]] | The religious and political roles of the [[Pharaoh]] | [[Peace treaty|Peace treaties]] |- | 9 | [[DB320|Secret Mummy Cave]] | [[Deir el-Bahri]] | [[Grave robbing]] and [[Body-snatching]] | Religious rituals |- | 10 | [[Valley of the Golden Mummies]] | [[Bahariya Oasis]] | Ancient Egyptian cultural influences on Ancient Greek and Roman cultures | Cultural interconnection |} ==External links== *[http://blog.discoveryeducation.com/blog/2008/03/26/dig-in-to-ancient-egypt/ Discovery Educator Network Blog Network: Dig in to Ancient Egypt] [[Category:Discovery Channel shows]] {{TV-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist |name = Eileen Barton |image =Eileen Barton.jpg |alt = |caption = |image_size = |background = solo_singer |birth_date = {{birth date|1924|11|24|mf=y}} |birth_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|2006|06|27|1924|11|24|mf=y}} |death_place = [[West Hollywood, California]], U.S. |genre = [[Traditional pop music|Traditional Pop]] |years_active = 1949–1950s |label = [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[National Records|National]], [[Mercury Records|Mercury]], [[Coral Records|Coral]] |website = }} '''Eileen Barton''' (November 24, 1924 – June 27, 2006) was an [[United States|American]] singer best known for her 1950 hit song, "[[If I Knew You Were Comin' I'd've Baked a Cake]]." ==Early years== Barton was born in [[Brooklyn, New York]]. Her birthdate is often given as 1929, but a certified copy of her birth certificate shows that she was born in 1924.{{cite web |url=http://www.familysearch.org/eng/search/frameset_search.asp?PAGE=/eng/search/ancestorsearchresults.asp |title=Family Search |publisher=The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints |accessdate=13 June 2012}} This was done commonly, to shave a few years from a performer's age. Eileen's parents, Benny and Elsie Barton, were [[vaudeville]] performers. She first appeared in her parents' act in Kansas City{{cite news|last1=Browning|first1=Norma Lee|title=The 'Bake a Cake' Girl Settles Down to Enjoy Life|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1966/06/07/page/39/article/the-bake-a-cake-girl-settles-down-to-enjoy-life|accessdate=18 September 2015|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=June 7, 1966|page=Section 2-Page 3}} at age 2½, singing "[[Ain't Misbehavin' (song)|Ain't Misbehavin']]," as a dare to her parents from columnist (and later radio star) Goodman Ace.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xT4aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KSUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3145,4288600&dq=goodman+ace&hl=en|title=Stars Fell For Barton|author=Pepan, Bea J.|date=8 June 1947|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal|accessdate=14 January 2011}} At 3½, she appeared at the [[Palace Theatre (Broadway)|Palace Theater]], doing two shows a day as part of comedian [[Ted Healy]]'s routine (Healy would go on to put together ''[[The Three Stooges]]''). ==Radio== Barton soon became a child star. By age 6, she appeared on ''[[The Horn and Hardart Children's Hour]]'', a [[radio]] program sponsored by [[Horn & Hardart|Horn & Hardart's Automat]], a then-well-known restaurant chain, and, by age 7, in 1936-37,Dunning, John. (1998). ''On the Air: The Encyclopedia of Old-Time Radio''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-507678-3}}. P. 174. she was working with [[Milton Berle]] on his ''Community Sing'' [[radio]] program, using the name "Jolly Gillette" and playing the sponsor's "daughter" (the sponsor was [[Global Gillette|Gillette Razors]]). She would ask to sing, he would tell her she couldn't, and she would remind him that her daddy was the sponsor, so he'd let her sing a current hit song. She also was a regular on ''The Milton Berle Show'' in 1939.Buxton, Frank and Owen, Bill (1972). ''The Big Broadcast: 1920-1950''. The Viking Press. SBN 670-16240-x. P. 160. At 8, she had a daily singing program of her own on [[WMCA (AM)|radio station WMCA]], ''Arnold's Dinner Club''. At 10, she appeared twice on [[Rudy Vallée]]'s network radio program in 1936.{{cite news|title=Barthelmess on Air with Vallee|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3242583/belvidere_daily_republican/|agency=Belvidere Daily Republican|date=April 9, 1936|page=5|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 17, 2015}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|title=The Short and Long of Radio|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3242633/the_evening_news/|agency=The Evening News|date=April 16, 1936|page=13|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 17, 2015}} {{Open access}} She also acted on radio series such as ''[[Death Valley Days]].'' At age 11, she left show business briefly. At age 14 she went on the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway stage]] as an understudy to [[Nancy Walker]] in ''[[Best Foot Forward (musical)|Best Foot Forward]],''{{cite web|title=Eileen Barton|url=http://www.playbillvault.com/Person/Detail/78101/Eileen-Barton|website=Playbill Vault|accessdate=18 September 2015}} followed by an appearance under her own name with [[Elaine Stritch]] in ''[[Angel in the Wings]].'' At age 15, she appeared as a guest singer on a [[Johnny Mercer]] variety series, leading to her being noticed by [[Frank Sinatra]], who took her under his wing and put her in a regular spot on the [[CBS]] radio show that he hosted in the 1940s. She co-starred on [[The Frank Sinatra Show (radio program)#The Frank Sinatra Show (Frank Sinatra In Person) (1944-45)|Sinatra's show]] beginning August 16, 1944,{{cite news|title=Eileen Barton with 'Voice'|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3242746/the_circleville_herald/|agency=The Circleville Herald|date=August 15, 1944|page=7|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 17, 2015}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|title=Templeton Guest On Sinatra's Show Wednesday Night|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3237986/harrisburg_telegraph/|agency=Harrisburg Telegraph|date=November 11, 1944|page=15|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 16, 2015}} {{Open access}} and was also part of Sinatra's act at the [[Paramount Theatre (Los Angeles)|Paramount Theater]] in 15 appearances there. She also appeared on her own and as a guest performer with such stars as Duke Ellington, [[Count Basie]], [[Nat King Cole]], and [[Danny Kaye]]. In 1945, Barton had her own [[radio]] program, ''Teen Timers.''{{cite news|title=Radio Guide Listening Post|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3237194/altoona_tribune/|agency=Altoona Tribune|date=September 25, 1945|page=12|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 16, 2015}} {{Open access}} That November, the program's name was changed to ''The Eileen Barton Show''. It was broadcast Saturday mornings on [[NBC]].{{cite news|title='Teen' Program Switch Nets Soxers 1 1/2 Hrs. Sat. Airtime|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kRgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&dq=%22Eileen+Barton+Show%22&source=bl&ots=vclN_z6bnj&sig=slK4Z9NEDZsaiNZtSi1LEHY5eg0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CHAQ6AEwEmoVChMI5JTPlbj_xwIVx8yACh0ZxQb7#v=onepage&q=%22Eileen%20Barton%20Show%22&f=false|accessdate=18 September 2015|agency=Billboard|date=November 24, 1945|page=8}} In 1954, she starred in ''The Eileen Barton Show'',Terrace, Vincent (1981), ''Radio's Golden Years: The Encyclopedia of Radio Programs 1930-1960''. A.S. Barnes & Company, Inc. {{ISBN|0-498-02393-1}}, p. 84. a 13-episode [[Electrical transcription|transcribed program]] for the United States Marine Corps.{{cite news|title=Marine Recruiting Show |url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/Archive-BC-IDX/54-OCR/1954-02-01-BC-OCR-Page-0078.pdf |accessdate=18 September 2015 |agency=Billboard |date=February 1, 1954 |page=78 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Television== Barton was a regular performer on ''[[The Swift Show]]'' in 1948, on ''[[Broadway Open House]]'' in 1951,Brooks, Tim & Marsh, Earle (1979). ''The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network TV Shows: 1946-Present''. Ballantine Books. {{ISBN|0-345-25525-9}}. Pp. 87, 604. and on ''[[The Bill Goodwin Show]]'' in 1951-52.McNeil, Alex (1996). ''Total Television''. Penguin Books USA, Inc. {{ISBN|0-14-02-4916-8}}. P. 98. She also appeared in 1961-62 as the "assistant mayor" of the TV game shows "Video Village" and "Video Village, Jr.".{{cite news|title=Game shows making strong comeback |url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/hd2/Archive-BC-IDX/61-OCR/1961-07-24-BC-OCR-Page-0062.pdf |accessdate=18 September 2015 |agency=Billboard |date=July 24, 1961 |page=62 }}{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Recording== Her first record, done for [[Capitol Records]], was "Would You Believe Me?" (catalog number 402), with the orchestra of [[Skitch Henderson|Lyle "Skitch" Henderson]], in 1948. In 1949 she cut the record of "[[If I Knew You Were Comin' I'd've Baked a Cake]]" (written by [[Bob Merrill]], [[Al Hoffman|Albert Hoffman]] and [[Al Trace]]; Trace used the pseudonym Clem Watts) and introduced it on [[Don McNeill (performer)|Don McNeill's]] radio program, ''[[Don McNeill's Breakfast Club|The Breakfast Club]].'' On the record, Trace's band musicians backed her, but were given billing as "The New Yorkers." It was first released by [[National Records]], a New York–based company mostly specializing in [[rhythm & blues]] records, as catalog number 9103, and when National's owner, Al Green, decided it was too big a seller for National to handle, it was later distributed by [[Mercury Records]],{{cite news|last1=Cross|first1=Leo H.|title=Chips From the Listening Post|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3237168/the_san_bernardino_county_sun/|agency=The San Bernardino County Sun|date=March 5, 1950|page=16|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 16, 2015}} {{Open access}} whose co-owner was Al Green's son, [[Irving Green]]. The record became one of the best-selling records on an independent label of all time, [[List of Billboard number-one singles of 1950|charting at #1]] best selling in stores for 2 weeks and most played by jockeys for 10 weeks, and altogether on the [[Billboard charts]] for over four months. In a 2005 interview for the liner-notes of her Jasmine Records CD release, Eileen indicated that she never received a penny in royalties from either National or Mercury for her record's success, although by contract she was supposed to receive 5% of each sale. After the success of this record, she became a [[night club]] and stage performer, appearing at all the important clubs in [[New York City]] and many others. In the 1950s, she was a featured singer with [[Guy Lombardo]] and his orchestra.{{cite news|title=Guy Lombardo Discovers Singers Are Expensive Item|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3237886/newport_daily_news/|agency=Newport Daily News|date=August 13, 1952|page=7|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 16, 2015}} {{Open access}} In 1956, Barton began recording for [[Epic Records]].{{cite news|title=The Disk Derby|url=http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1956/09/01/page/14/article/the-disk-derby|accessdate=18 September 2015|agency=Chicago Tribune|date=September 1, 1956|page=Part 1-Page 14}} She continued to record for both National and Mercury, making "Honey, Won't You Honeymoon with Me?" (catalog number 9109) and "May I Take Two Giant Steps?" (catalog number 9112) for National and "[[You Brought a New Kind of Love]]" (catalog number 5410) for Mercury. Later she moved over to [[Coral Records]], and charted with some cover versions of songs that were bigger hits for other artists, such as "[[Cry (Churchill Kohlman song)|Cry]]", "[[Sway (song)|Sway]]", and others. She also appeared in motion pictures and television, working the restaurant and night club circuit well into the 1970s. ==Personal life== Barton married industrialist Dan Shaw in Juarez, Mexico, April 15, 1961.{{cite news|title=Eileen Barton Weds Executive|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3238018/the_indiana_gazette/|agency=The Indiana Gazette|date=April 20, 1961|page=5|via = [[Newspapers.com]]|accessdate = September 16, 2015}} {{Open access}} ==Death== Barton died at her [[West Hollywood]] home from [[ovarian cancer]] at the age of 81. She had no children and was not married at the time of her death. ==Hit records== {|class="wikitable" |- !Year !Single ![[Billboard Hot 100|US
Chart]]{{cite book |title=Pop Memories: 1890-1954|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|year=1986|publisher=Record Research|isbn=0-89820-083-0}} |- |rowspan="2"|1950 |"[[If I Knew You Were Comin' I'd've Baked a Cake|If I Knew You Were Comin' (I'd've Baked a Cake)]]" |align="center"|1 |- |"May I Take Two Giant Steps?" |align="center"|25 |- |1951 |"[[Cry (Churchill Kohlman song)|Cry]]" |align="center"|10 |- |1952 |"Wishin'" |align="center"|30 |- |rowspan="3"|1953 |"[[Pretend (song)|Pretend]]" |align="center"|17 |- |"[[Don't Let the Stars Get in Your Eyes]]" |align="center"|24 |- |"Toys" |align="center"|21 |- |rowspan="3"|1954 |"Don't Ask Me Why" |align="center"|25 |- |"[[Pine Tree, Pine over Me]]" |align="center"|26 |- |"[[Sway (song)|Sway (¿Quién será?)]]" |align="center"|21 |- |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikipedia books|Eileen Barton}} * {{IMDb name|name=Eileen Barton|id=0059137}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080201190744/http://www.saxonyrecordcompany.com/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=210 Photo Gallery of Eileen Barton] * [http://www.radiogoldindex.com/cgi-local/p2.cgi?ProgramName=The+Eileen+Barton+Show Episodic log of ''The Eileen Barton Show'' from radioGOLDINdex] {{Eileen Barton}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barton, Eileen}} [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:Deaths from ovarian cancer]] [[Category:Musicians from Brooklyn]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in California]] [[Category:Savoy Records artists]] [[Category:Crest Records artists]] [[Category:Capitol Records artists]] [[Category:Mercury Records artists]] [[Category:Burials at Westwood Village Memorial Park Cemetery]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:20th-century women singers]] [[Category:Coral Records artists]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/77.187.235.152|77.187.235.152]] ([[User talk:77.187.235.152|talk]]): Rm spamlink. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
'''Flicker-free''' is a term given to [[video display]]s, primarily [[cathode ray tube]]s, operating at a high [[refresh rate]] to reduce or eliminate the perception of [[Flicker (screen)|screen flicker]]. For televisions, this involves operating at a '''100 Hz''' or '''120 Hz''' [[hertz]] [[field rate]] to eliminate flicker, compared to standard televisions that operate at 50 Hz ([[PAL]], [[SÉCAM]] [[broadcast television system|systems]]) or 60 Hz ([[NTSC]]), most simply done by displaying each field twice, rather than once. For computer displays, this is usually a refresh rate of 70–90 Hz, sometimes 100 Hz or higher. This should not be confused with [[motion interpolation]], though they may be combined – see [[#Implementation|implementation]], below.
Televisions operating at these frequencies are often labelled as being 100 or 120 Hz without using the words ''flicker-free'' in the description.
== Prevalence == The term is primarily used for CRTs, especially televisions in 50 Hz countries (PAL or SECAM) and computer monitors from the 1990s and early 2000s – the 50 Hz rate of PAL/SECAM video (compared with 60 Hz NTSC video) and the relatively large computer monitors and close viewing distances of 1990s/2000s computer monitors (hence making more of the screen in the viewer's [[peripheral vision]]) make flicker most noticeable on these devices.
Contrary to popular belief, modern LCD monitors are not flicker free, since most of them use [[pulse-width modulation]] (PWM) for brightness control. As the brightness setting is lowered, the flicker becomes more noticeable, since the period when the backlight is active in each PWM duty cycle shortens. The problem is much more pronounced on modern LED backlit monitors, because LED backlight reacts faster to changes in current. == Implementation == The goal is to display images sufficiently frequently to exceed the human [[flicker fusion threshold]], and hence create the impression of a constant (non-flickering) source.
In computer displays this consists of changing the frame rate of the produced signal in the [[video card]] (and in sync with this, the displayed image on the display). This is limited by the clock speed of the video adapter and frame rate required of the program – for a given pixel clock speed, higher refresh rates require lower resolution or color depth, and higher frame rates require that the program producing the video recalculate the screen more frequently. For these reasons, refresh rates above 90–100 Hz to reduce flicker are uncommon on computers – these rates are sufficient to eliminate flicker.
On television, this is more involved, as the source material has a fixed frame rate (and is also traditionally [[interlaced video]], in which one-half of the scan lines of each frame are broadcast at a time). Most simply, the frame rate can be doubled by simply displaying the same broadcast image twice in rapid succession, as is done with [[movie projector]]s (which display each frame of 24 fps film two or more times) – either displaying each field twice or alternating fields.
Alternatively, this can involve [[motion interpolation]], where rather than displaying the original fields twice, creates interpolated images between the original frames. This may be combined with [[deinterlacing]], converting the image to [[progressive scan]] (attempting to create a full picture from the two half images).
Higher refresh rates, while they reduce flicker, may cause other problems. Simply redisplaying the fields may cause [[judder]], particularly on fast moving images, as the image is displayed repeatedly in the same location, rather than moving smoothly. Conversely, interpolation (which avoids judder and may create more fluid motion than in the original video) can instead cause blurring, particularly visible on fast scrolling text. See [[motion interpolation]] for further discussion.
== See also == *[[Flicker (screen)]] *[[Flicker fusion threshold]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
*[http://www.tftcentral.co.uk/articles/pulse_width_modulation.htm Pulse Width Modulation] Effects of PWM used in LCD brightness control
[[Category:Display technology]] [[Category:Television technology]]

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2015}} '''Franeleros''' are people who have as main activity guarding or keeping an eye on cars parked in several streets in certain places in large [[Mexico|Mexican]] cities, getting a [[Tipping by region#Mexico|tip]] as a reward, which sometimes is established by them. The term comes from the Spanish word ''franela'', meaning flannel, which is a small piece of soft light fabric (normally washed out [[red]] or [[gray]]) which they use to wash the cars if they are asked to, or to simply wave it around to give parking indications. ''Franeleros'' are sometimes also known as ''cuida-coches'' (car keepers) or ''"viene vienes"'' (literally "come come"), which is the phrase they commonly say while giving the parking indications. In 2007, due to the criticisms around this controversial "occupation" (mainly [[extortion]], [[Motor vehicle theft|grand theft auto]], relation with [[organized crime]] and illegal use of [[public space]]) this guarding activity became illegal in [[Mexico City]], but it is still widely practiced. In areas where [[Parking in Mexico City|parking meters have been installed]], franeleros no longer operate.
A central tenet of ''franeleros'' is the implicit threat that they will intentionally [[Property damage|destroy or vandalize]] cars if the owner does not pay them, making the activity a form of [[extortion]]. Franeleros will often block empty spaces with trashcans, empty jugs, flowerpots or bricks, and remove them when their "customers" park.
[[File:Anti_franelero_banner,_colonia_Roma,Mexico_City.jpg|thumbnail|Banner exhorting citizens not to give money to ''franeleros'' in Colonia Roma, Mexico City, August 2016]]
==Location== ''Franeleros'' are commonly located in big and medium size cities, especially in areas with a big demand for parking spaces; they may also be present when parking lots have high fares. They are usually found around touristic places (such as [[Mexico City]] downtown and [[Coyoacán]]), universities and schools, business and office areas (notably [[Santa Fe (Mexico City)|Santa Fe]] and [[Polanco (Mexico)|Polanco]]), [[shopping mall]]s, night life areas, restaurants, banks, markets, supermarkets and commercial zones. Since many of these places in Mexico often have a poor parking infrastructure, limited offer of parking spaces, high fares in parking lots, or simply an unusually high demand for parking spaces, many drivers leave their cars in streets, which attracts ''franeleros'' who are eager to earn tips.
==Tipping== Although tipping ''franeleros'' or not and the amount given should be optional for the driver as it is only a [[Gratuity|tip]] (optional by definition), it is often seen that ''franeleros'' ask for fixed amounts of money. The tip usually ranges from 2 to 30 [[Mexican pesos]] (0.2 - 3 [[USD]]), being this quantity a function of the:
*'''Area -''' ''Franeleros'' ask for bigger tips in business areas, getting up to 20 [[MXN]] (Mexican pesos) per car for the entire day. With people who use their "service" daily, they usually make a weekly arrangement which implies a 10-20% reduction; with this arrangement they sometimes save up a space for their [[customer|client]] and they might even serve as [[valet parking]]. In touristic places and universities they often ask from 5 to 15 MXN for the while. In medium demand places such as supermarkets and other commercial zones people tip them with 2 to 5 MXP; these places are of the few to remain really optional to tip. The highest tips are asked around night life areas, which normally lack adequate parking spaces; in this places ''franeleros'' ask from 15 to 30 MXP. In extremely high demand situations (concerts and sports events), they may even charge 50 to 100 MXN. *'''Space availability -''' Higher demand implies a higher tip. In some areas where there is continuous and permanent high affluence of cars (like business areas and universities), there are more ''franeleros'' and the tips they ask are higher. *'''Time spent in the place -''' ''These people'' sometimes ask for their tip according to the time that the car spent on "their" space. If it is really fast, the tip could be small and may even remain optional. For longer periods of time the ask for more. Sometimes they ask the driver how long will he/she delay to say an amount. *'''Time of the day -''' As explained above, ''franeleros'' ask for more money during the night, even if it is the same place. Also at peak hours where there is less availability they charge more to find a space. *'''Car's brand -''' ''Franeleros'' sometimes ask for bigger sums of money if it is an expensive car, inferring that if the driver has a good car, he/she might also have more money. *'''Presence of other ''franeleros'' and parking lots -''' ''Franeleros'' sometimes compete among themselves, they reserve certain parking spaces for themselves and charge less or more to generate more income. If there is a parking lot nearby, they usually charge less than its tariff to give an incentive to drivers to leave their car with them. *'''Presence of police in the area -''' As this activity became formally [[Law|illegal]] in 2007 in some Mexican cities, sometimes ''franeleros'' incur in [[bribery]] to be allowed to do their "work". If this is the case, they charge more money so they are able to bribe the [[police]] daily and still have some income. This practice has led to corruption in many police organizations.
==See also== * [[Parking in Mexico City]] * ''[[Trapito]]''
==References== *[http://www.franeleros.com Franeleros.com] Website completely dedicated to show the negative impact of this "occupation" on the society
[[Category:Informal occupations]] [[Category:Street performance]] [[Category:Parking]] [[Category:Road transportation in Mexico]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Julie A. Baroh | image = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1970|8|4}} | image_size = | caption = | birth_place = [[Seattle]], Washington | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | occupation = Artist | known for = [[Fantasy art]] | nationality = American | alma mater = [[Cornish College of the Arts]] ([[Bachelors of Fine Arts|BFA]]) | website = [http://www.fairyartists.com/julie-baroh.shtml Fairy Artists]
[http://www.juliebaroh.com/ Julie Baroh's glass blowing] }} '''Julie Baroh''' (b. August 4, 1970) is an American [[fantasy artist]] who also works in [[Glassblowing|glass]]. ==Life and activities== Julie Baroh was born in [[Seattle]], Washington on August 4, 1970. Majoring in sculpture and [[printmaking]] at the [[Cornish College of the Arts]], she received her [[Bachelors of Fine Arts|BFA]] in 1994. While still in college, she was recruited to work for the gaming company [[Wizards of the Coast]] as a freelance artist and published work in the company's magazines ''[[Scrye]]'' and ''[[The Duelist]]'' as well as illustrations for the [[collectible card game]], [[Magic: The Gathering]] throughout the 1990s. After training in graphic and network applications, Baroh worked for [[Adobe Systems]] in the late 1990s, before leaving "to return to her fine arts roots".Frank, p. 84 In the first decade of the 21st century, she published work in ''Watercolor Fairies: A Step by Step Guide to Creating the Fairy World'', ''The Art of Faery'' and the ''Big Book of Contemporary Illustration''. Baroh was art director of the magazine ''Blood and Thunder'' for a year and a contributing layout designer for two years. She "specializes in whimsical animals and characters painted with a light touch, set in a fantasy realm: goblins and fairies, and mythological flora and fauna. In her fine art she pursues figuration and portraiture, using classical drawing techniques. Most of her work is done in watercolor or gouache." ==Personal life== Baroh is married and is a member of the [[artist collective]] Krab Jab Studio and the Seattle Illustrator's Collective. ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{cite book|last1=Frank|first1=Jane|title=Role-playing Game and Collectible Card Game Artists: A Biographical Dictionary|date=2012|publisher=McFarland|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=978-0-7864-4610-0}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baroh, Julie}} [[Category:1970 births]] [[Category:American artists]] [[Category:Game artists]] [[Category:Living people]]
